title: Sir David Wedderburn, 3rd Baronet
text:
Sir David Wedderburn, 3rd Baronet (20 December 1835 – 18 September 1882) was a British politician.
Life.
David Wedderburn was the second son of <a href="Sir%20John%20Wedderburn%2C%202nd%20Baronet">Sir John Wedderburn, 2nd Baronet</a>, and Henrietta Louise Milburn. His grandfather, <a href="Sir%20David%20Wedderburn%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir David</a>, had had the title of the <a href="Wedderburn%20baronets">Wedderburn baronetcy</a> restored to the family, following the <a href="attainder">attainder</a> after the <a href="Jacobite%20rising%20of%201745">Jacobite rising of 1745</a> and the subsequent regain of fortune via the <a href="Sugar%20plantations%20in%20the%20Caribbean">slave sugar plantations of Jamaica</a>.
He studied law at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>, where he graduated as senior optime in 1858. He was called to the <a href="Faculty%20of%20Advocates">Scottish bar</a> as an advocate in 1861. He succeeded to the title upon his father's death in 1862, his elder brother John having died in the <a href="Indian%20Rebellion%20of%201857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a>.
He was a <a href="justice%20of%20the%20peace">justice of the peace</a> for <a href="Midlothian">Midlothian</a> and a captain in the Midlothian Yeomanry.
He was elected as a <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="South%20Ayrshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">South Ayrshire</a> in 1868, holding the seat until 1874. He was then elected for <a href="Haddington%20Burghs%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Haddington Burghs</a> in <a href="1879%20Haddington%20Burghs%20by-election">1879</a>, resigning in 1882 by becoming <a href="Steward%20of%20the%20Manor%20of%20Northstead">Steward of the Manor of Northstead</a>.
In April 1873, he visited <a href="Victor%20Hugo">Victor Hugo</a> in <a href="Guernsey">Guernsey</a>. He confessed his <a href="Republicanism%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">republican convictions</a> to the great French poet, but added : "If I said that aloud, I would not be re-elected".
He travelled widely, returning to India as an adult, and visiting the United States, Canada, China, Japan, Java, Iceland, South Africa, and throughout Europe. His travel journals and his political writings were edited and published after his death by his youngest sister, Louisa Jane, assisted by her husband Edward Hope Percival. He wrote for "<a href="The%20Nineteenth%20Century%20%28periodical%29">The Nineteenth Century</a>" and "<a href="The%20Fortnightly%20Review">The Fortnightly Review</a>", two of the most prominent periodicals of the time.
He lived at <a href="Inveresk">Inveresk</a> Lodge, south of <a href="Musselburgh">Musselburgh</a>. He never married. On his death in 1882, the title went to his youngest brother, <a href="William%20Wedderburn">William Wedderburn</a>, one of the founders of the <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">Indian National Congress</a>.
He is buried in St. Michael's churchyard in Inveresk. The grave lies midway along the western boundary of the original churchyard, backing onto the Victorian cemetery.
